content: At a birthday party, Sarah, Jane, and Tom are playing hide-and-seek. Sarah is the seeker, while Jane and Tom go to hide. Jane hides under the bed, and Tom hides inside the closet. Meanwhile, Sarah's mom calls her downstairs to help set up the cake. During this time, Jane sneaks out from under the bed and hides in the bathroom instead. Tom, however, stays in the closet. When Sarah returns to continue seeking, where does she think Jane is hiding?

Let's see. So, Sarah is the seeker in the game of hide-and-seek, and Jane and Tom are hiding. Initially, Jane hides under the bed, and Tom hides inside the closet. Then, Sarah's mom calls her downstairs to help set up the cake. During this time, Jane changes her hiding spot from under the bed to the bathroom, while Tom stays put in the closet.

Now, the question is, when Sarah returns to continue seeking, where does she think Jane is hiding?

Hmm. Well, Sarah last knew that Jane was hiding under the bed. Since she was called away and didn't see Jane move to the bathroom, she probably still thinks Jane is under the bed. Unless, of course, someone told her otherwise, but from the story, no one did.

So, I think Sarah would still look under the bed for Jane, believing that's where she's hiding, not knowing that Jane has moved to the bathroom.

But maybe there's more to consider. Perhaps Sarah might think that Jane could have moved to another hiding spot while she was away. Kids often change hiding spots in hide-and-seek to make it harder to be found. So, maybe Sarah would consider that possibility.

On the other hand, since Sarah was called away and didn't see Jane move, she might assume that Jane stayed where she was. Also, Tom stayed in the closet, so maybe Sarah thinks both are in their original spots.

Alternatively, maybe Sarah would check the last known location first, which is under the bed, and if Jane is not there, she would look elsewhere, possibly including the bathroom.
